attributes.text: The data binding package is still under development so there will be changes to the API. This Features is for testing purpose only.
Static debug flag to enable log messages on every invoke of a listener
The source of the binding.
The event of the source object which could be the change event in common but has to be an {@link qx.event.type.Data} event.
The object which the source should be bind to.
The property name of the target object.
A map containing the options. See {@link #bind} for more information.
The index of the given array if its an array to bind.

Internal helper method which is actually doing all bindings. That means that an event listener will be added to the source object which listens to the given event and invokes an set on the target property on the targetObject. This method does not store the binding in the internal reference store so it should NOT be used from outside this class. For an outside usage, use {@link #bind}.

Returns the internal id for that binding. This can be used for referencing the binding or e.g. for removing. This is not an atomic id so you can’t you use it as a hash-map index. It’s the id which will be returned by the {@link qx.core.Object#addListener} method.
If the event is no data event or there is no property definition for the target object and target property.
The current context for the listener.
Event listener for the chaining of the properties.
The array containing the property names. Attention, this method can chang this parameter!!!
Checks for an array element in the given property names and adapts the arrays to fit the algorithm.
An array containing the values of the array properties corresponding to the property names.
The value which possibly should be converted.
The target object.
The property name of the target object.
The options map which can includes the converter. For a detailed information on the map, take a look at {@link #bind}.

This method takes the given value, checks if the user has given a converter and converts the value to its target type. If no converter is given by the user, the {@link #__defaultConversion} will try to convert the value.
The converted value. If no conversion has been done, the value property will be returned.
If there is no property definition of the given target object and target property.
The data to convert.
The value of the check property. That usually contains the target type.
Tries to convert the data to the type given in the targetCheck argument.
The object to check.
The name of the property.
Helper method which tries to figure out if the given property on the given object does have a change event and if returns the name of it.
The name of the change event.
If there is no property definition of the given object property pair.
The source where the property is stored.
The name of the property.

Tries to return a fitting event name to the given source object and property name. First, it assumes that the propertyname is a real property and therefore it checks the property definition for the event. The second possibility is to check if there is an event with the given name. The third and last possibility checked is if there is an event which is named change + propertyname. If this three possibilities fail, an error will be thrown.
The name of the corresponding property.
The object where the property chain starts.
The names of the properties, separated with a dot.
Helper-Function resolving the object on which the last property of the chain should be set.
The object on which the last property should be set.
The object where the property chain starts.
The names of the properties, separated with a dot.
Resets the value of the given target after resolving the target property chain.
The value to set.
The object which contains the target property.
The name of the target property in the target object.
The options map perhaps containing the user defined converter.
The source object of the binding ( used for the onUpdate callback).
Set the given value to the target property. This method is used for initially set the value.
The object where the property chain starts.
The names of the properties, separated with a dot.
The value to set.
Sets the given value to the given target after resolving the target property chain.
The source of the binding.
The property chain which represents the source property.
The object which the source should be bind to.
The property name of the target object.
The options map perhaps containing the user defined converter.
Internal helper for setting up the listening to the changes on the target side of the binding. Only works if the target property is a property chain
A map containing the listener ids and the targets.
The listener id of the id for a deeper binding.
The source Object of the binding.
The name of the source event.
The target object.
The name of the property on the target object.
This method stores the given value as a binding in the internal structure of all bindings.
The source of the binding.
The property chain which represents the source property.
The object which the source should be bind to.
The property name of the target object.
The options map perhaps containing the user defined converter.
Helper for updating the target. Gets the current set data from the source and set that on the target.
The source of the binding.
The property chain which represents the source property.
The object which the source should be bind to.
The property chain to the target object.

A map containing the options.

  • converter: A converter function which takes two parameters and should return the converted value. The first parameter is the data so convert and the second one is the corresponding model object, which is only set in case of the use of an controller. If no conversion has been done, the given value should be returned.
  • onUpdate: A callback function can be given here. This method will be called if the binding was updated successful. There will be three parameter you do get in that method call: the source object, the target object and the data as third parameter.
  • onSetFail: A callback function can be given here. This method will be called if the set of the value fails.

The function is responsible for binding a source objects property to a target objects property. Both properties have to have the usual qooxdoo getter and setter. The source property also needs to fire change-events on every change of its value. Please keep in mind, that this binding is unidirectional. If you need a binding in both directions, you have to use two of this bindings.

It’s also possible to bind some kind of a hierarchy as a source. This means that you can separate the source properties with a dot and bind by that the object referenced to this property chain. Example with an object ‘a’ which has object ‘b’ stored in its ‘child’ property. Object b has a string property named abc:

qx.data.SingleValueBinding.bind(a, "child.abc", textfield, "value");

In that case, if the property abc of b changes, the textfield will automatically contain the new value. Also if the child of a changes, the new value (abc of the new child) will be in the textfield.

There is also a possibility of binding an array. Therefor the array {@link qx.data.IListData} is needed because this array has change events which the native does not. Imagine a qooxdoo object a which has a children property containing an array holding more of its own kind. Every object has a name property as a string.

var svb = qx.data.SingleValueBinding;
// bind the first childs name of 'a' to a textfield
svb.bind(a, "children[0].name", textfield, "value");
// bind the last childs name of 'a' to a textfield
svb.bind(a, "children[last].name", textfield2, "value");
// also deeper bindinds are possible
svb.bind(a, "children[0].children[0].name", textfield3, "value");

As you can see in this example, the abc property of a’s b will be bound to the textfield. If now the value of b changed or even the a will get a new b, the binding still shows the right value.
Returns the internal id for that binding. This can be used for referencing the binding or e.g. for removing. This is not an atomic id so you can’t you use it as a hash-map index.
If the event is no data event or there is no property definition for object and property (source and target).

Returns a map containing for every bound object an array of data binding information. The key of the map is the hashcode of the bound objects. Every binding is represented by an array containing id, sourceObject, sourceEvent, targetObject and targetProperty.
Map containing all bindings.
The object of which the bindings should be returned.
Returns an array which lists all bindings.
An array of binding informations. Every binding information is an array itself containing id, sourceObject, sourceEvent, targetObject and targetProperty in that order.
Removes all binding in the whole application. After that not a single binding is left.
The object of which the bindings should be removed.
Removes all bindings for the given object.
If the object is not in the internal registry of the bindings.
If one of the bindings listed internally can not be removed.
The source object of the binding.
The id of the binding.
Removes the binding with the given id from the given sourceObject. The id hast to be the id returned by any of the bind functions.
If the binding could not be found.
Debug function which shows all bindings in the log console. To get only one binding in the console use {@link #showBindingInLog}
the source of the binding.
The id of the binding.
Debug function which shows some valuable information about the given binding in console. For that it uses {@link qx.log.Logger}.
